  • 一定要想想你希望别人如何告诉你。某天你可能不得不传递的一条消息是你离开的消息。事实上，您可能已经有过辞去工作或从一个团队调到另一个团队的经历。你是如何传达这个消息的？你发备忘录了吗？好吧，也许是对人力资源部，但对团队的其他人来说，如果你认为他们想在公开之前知道，你可能会把他们拉到一边面对面地告诉他们。你可能举办了告别派对，写了一封告别信，或者向团队做了最后一次演讲，讲述了你在公司期间学到的东西。在某些情况下庆祝这些悲伤的变化是可以的，只要你能优雅地做到这一点。所有这些经验教训都适用于向您的团队传递重大消息。
问 CTO：我有一个非技术老板

这是我第一次遇到非技术型的老板，事实证明这真的很难。我如何有效地处理这种关系？

This is the first time I’ve ever had a boss who was nontechnical, and it’s turning out to be really hard. How do I effectively manage this relationship?

我第一次遇到完全非技术经理是在我开始向 Rent the Runway 的 CEO 汇报工作时。向非技术经理报告可能是一种完全的文化冲突。幸运的是，一些最佳实践将帮助您管理这种关系：

The first time I ever experienced a fully nontechnical manager was when I started reporting to the CEO at Rent the Runway. Reporting to a nontechnical manager can be a total culture clash. Fortunately, a few best practices will help you manage this relationship:

  • 不要用行话隐藏信息，注意细节。你的新老板可能非常聪明，但他可能没有耐心听技术行话，而且他不太可能想听到大量关于细微技术决策的细节。此过程的一部分是学习区分对交流有价值的信息类型和没有价值的信息类型。
  • 预计您将需要与新老板进行一对一的交流，因此请准备好一系列主题。忙碌的高管很难确定，令人沮丧；即使获得 1-1 次也是一个挑战，所以不要浪费你的时间。到目前为止，您可能期望双方在会议上提出一些特定主题，但现在不一定如此，所以请务必做好准备。如果您在 1-1 时间兑现时遇到困难，请提前发送议程以提醒您的老板您需要她的关注 - 与管理她日历的行政助理保持良好关系永远不会有坏处！
  • 尝试带来解决方案，而不是要解决的问题。CEO们通常不想听到事情是如何失败的，他们也不想听到你与同事的分歧或你在管理方面遇到的麻烦。如果您的 CEO 不想听到太多问题，请尊重您不会在管理方面从他那里得到太多指导，并找另一个人从中获得指导。话虽如此，不要回避传达坏消息。
  • 请教。提出解决方案听起来与我的建议背道而驰，但没有什么比征求别人的意见更能体现尊重了。你的老板可能不想被困在解决你的问题中，但你可以打赌，如果你将其表述为需要建议，她会很乐意提供反馈。
  • 不要害怕重复自己。如果你提出了一个似乎被遗忘的重要问题，如果它真的很重要，请再次提出。在获得任何牵引力之前，您可能需要这样做几次。三倍往往是神奇的数字。
  • 支持。始终询问您是否可以做更多的事情来提供帮助。尽可能多地表明你在那里支持你的老板和公司。
  • 积极地在其他地方寻求指导和技能发展。您不再有经理；你有一个老板。第一次担任高级领导职位时，您可能仍需要进行一些技能培养，因此请一位教练，要求接受培训，并在公司外部创建一个同行小组来支持您度过这个勇敢的新世界。

其他职能部门的高级同行

Senior Peers in Other Functions

当我进入高级管理层时，我的许多重大启示都涉及我需要与执行和领导团队中的其他人发展的关系。我有机会在许多职能部门与我尊敬的人一起工作，而且由于我们拥有庞大而多元化的领导团队，我结识了许多不同类型的高级领导。我与某些人相处得比其他人更好，并且我通过从两种类型的互动中学习来发展我的观点。

Many of the major revelations for me as I moved into senior management involved the relationships that I needed to develop with the other people on the executive and leadership teams. I had the opportunity to work with people I respected across many functions, and because we had a large and diverse leadership team I got to know many different types of senior leaders. I got along better with some than with others, and I evolved my perspective by learning from both types of interactions.

与公司中的任何其他团队相比，高级领导者必须积极实践以一线团队为中心（在第 6 章中介绍）。他们首先致力于业务及其成功，其次致力于其部门的成功，以此作为促进整体业务成功的一种方式。诸如 Patrick Lencioni 的The Five Dysfunctions of a Team 2之类的领导力书籍描述了这种关系，虽然我们中的许多人开始与其他工程经理一起实践这种类型的领导力作为我们的“第一团队”，但高级领导力通常是您的同事第一次所有人的运作方式都与您习惯的方式截然不同，并且在您的第一个团队中几乎没有同事是工程师，这会让人感到非常孤立。

Senior leaders, more than any other group in a company, must actively practice first-team focus (introduced in Chapter 6). They are dedicated first and foremost to the business and its success, and secondly to the success of their departments as a way of contributing to the overall business success. Leadership books such as Patrick Lencioni’s The Five Dysfunctions of a Team2 write about this relationship, and while many of us start to practice this type of leadership with other engineering managers as our “first team,” senior leadership is often the first time your peers all operate in a very different way than you’re used to, and having few to no peers on your first team who are fellow engineers can feel very isolating.

那么，与跨职能同事合作愉快是什么感觉呢？首先，你让他们拥有他们的区域，他们也让你拥有你的区域。我们中的许多人在职业生涯的早期就学会了如何做到这一点，那时我们必须与高级设计师、产品经理或其他业务团队成员一起工作，但如果你还没有学会如何让同事拥有她的专长，现在是时间。当涉及到她的地盘时，尊重她是最基本的。如果你不同意她的管理风格或在不直接影响你的团队的地方应用她的技能，你对待这种分歧就像对待一个碰巧和你不爱的人约会的好朋友一样。除非她征求你的意见，否则尽量远离它，当然要善待你选择讨论的任何分歧。

So what does it feel like to work well with cross-functional peers? To start with, you let them own their areas, and they let you own yours. Many of us learn how to do this earlier in our careers, when we have to work with senior designers, product managers, or other business team members, but if you haven’t learned how to let a peer own her specialty, now is the time. Giving her respectful deference when it comes to her turf is fundamental. If you disagree with her management style or application of her skill set in places where it isn’t directly affecting your team, you treat that disagreement like you would treat a good friend who happens to date people you don’t love. Unless she asks for your advice, try to stay out of it as much as possible, and certainly approach any disagreement you choose to discuss with kindness. Be willing to let those differences lie.

当然，你会不同意你的同龄人。这种分歧的发生地点要么是一对一，要么是在你的领导团队会议上。在这些会议上，您可以就战略、公司面临的挑战以及方向设定的细节讨论意见分歧。如果这些数字没有意义，请在这些会议的背景下询问首席财务官。还期望在此设置中捍卫自己的技术决策和路线图。

Of course, you’ll disagree with your peers. The place for this disagreement is either one-on-one or in your leadership team meetings. These meetings are where you hash out differences of opinion on strategy, challenges the company is facing, and details of direction setting. If the numbers don’t make sense, ask the CFO in the context of these meetings. Also expect to defend your own technical decisions and roadmap in this setting.

这将我们带到信任的第二个要素，超越信任某人的能力。在团队的五种功能障碍中，伦乔尼指出，缺乏信任是一种基本的功能障碍。在这种情况下，缺少的是相信你的同事正在积极地为组织尽最大努力，他们不会试图操纵情况、破坏你或以其他方式为所欲为。因此，除了对你的同事对他们的地盘的所有权建立基本的尊重和尊重他们作为职能专家的能力之外，你还必须抛开他们在不同意你的观点时以非理性或自利的方式行事的想法你不喜欢的东西。

This brings us to the second element of trust, beyond trusting someone’s abilities. In The Five Dysfunctions of a Team, Lencioni notes that absence of trust is a fundamental dysfunction. In this case, what’s missing is the trust that your peers are actively trying to do their best for the organization, that they are not trying to manipulate situations, undermine you, or otherwise get their own way. So, beyond establishing basic respect for your peers’ ownership of their turf and respect for their abilities as functional experts, you also have to put aside the idea that they’re acting in irrational or self-interested ways when they disagree with you or do things you don’t like.

建立这种基本的信任确实很困难。您可能会与某些（如果不是全部）同龄人发生某种程度的文化冲突。造就出色 CTO 的价值观可能与造就出色 CFO、CMO、运营副总裁等的价值观略有不同。极度分析驱动的人与更具创造力或直觉的人之间经常发生冲突。另一个是喜欢拥抱敏捷和变化（是的，有时是无序的）的人与那些推动更长期计划、截止日期和预算的人之间的人。你必须弄清楚如何理解和信任每个人的风格。

Establishing this fundamental trust is really difficult. You will probably have some degree of a cultural clash with some, if not all, of your peers. The values that make a great CTO are probably slightly different from those that make a great CFO, CMO, VP of Operations, and so on. A very common clash occurs between people who are extremely analytically driven and those who are more creatively or intuitively focused. Another is between the people who prefer to embrace agility and change (and, yes, sometimes disorder) and those who push for more long-term planning, deadlines, and budgets. You have to figure out how to understand and trust everyone’s styles across the spectrum.

工程师们经常在过渡到尊重​​不同的同行并与他们进行良好沟通的过程中挣扎。我相信与尊重的斗争是当前技术文化的副作用，它告诉我们工程师是房间里最聪明的人。怎么说都不为过：没有分析驱动力的同龄人并不愚蠢。另一方面，当我们不说话时，我们会损害自己，以便非技术同行能够理解我们在说什么。向不熟悉它的人——甚至不需要熟悉它的人——抛出行话会让他们觉得我们很愚蠢。因此，我们需要弄清楚如何以一种智能但非技术同行可以理解的方式来传达我们工作的复杂性。

Engineers frequently struggle with the transition to respecting and communicating well with diverse peers. I believe the struggle with respect is a side effect of the current tech culture, which tells us that engineers are the smartest people in the room. It can’t be said strongly enough: your peers who are not analytically driven are not stupid. On the flip side, we undermine ourselves when we fail to talk so that nontechnical peers can understand what we’re saying. Throwing out jargon to people who aren’t familiar with it — and who don’t even need to be familiar with it — makes us look stupid to them. We therefore need to figure out how to communicate the complexity of our work in a way that an intelligent but nontechnical peer can understand.

这种对一线队的信任和尊重的最后一个要素是沉默锥。在更广泛的团队中不存在领导团队中发生的分歧。一旦做出决定，我们就会致力于该决定，并在我们的工程团队和公司其他任何人面前统一战线。说起来容易做起来难——我经常努力隐藏自己与同龄人的分歧。当你没有如愿以偿时放手，特别是当你觉得你的反对意见没有被听到时，放手是很难的，而且它必须时不时地发生。特别是在这个级别，您必须决定是要排队还是退出。中间立场，公开不同意你的同行，只会让每个人的情况变得更糟。

The final element of this first-team trust and respect is the cone of silence. Disagreements that happen in the context of the leadership team don’t exist to the wider team. Once a decision is made, we commit to that decision and put on a united front in front of our engineering teams and anyone else in the company. It’s easier said than done — I’ve struggled frequently with hiding my own disagreements with my peers. Letting go when you don’t get your way, especially when you don’t feel that your objections have been heard, is hard, and it will have to happen from time to time. At this level especially, you must decide whether you want to fall in line or quit. The middle ground, openly disagreeing with your peers, does nothing but make the situation worse for everyone.

回声

The Echo

作为组织中最高层的人，你将受到比你一生中任何时候都更密切的关注。你的出现让人们把所有的注意力都集中在你身上。他们寻求你的认可，并尽量避免你的批评。将你的心态从“团队中的一员”转变为“负责人”，尤其是当你从团队中脱颖而出并自己发展团队时，对这个级别的许多人来说是一个挑战。

As the senior-most person in an organization, you’ll be watched more closely than you’ve ever been watched in your life. Your presence causes people to focus all of their attention on you. They seek out your approval and try to avoid your criticism. Shifting your mindset away from “one of the team” to “the person in charge,” especially if you came up through the team and grew the team yourself, is a challenge for many at this level.

你不再是团队中的一员。您的第一个团队由领导/执行级别的同事组成，您的报告结构现在已成为您的第二个团队。如果你成功地转变了你的思维方式，你可能会开始在社交上与整个组织有点脱离。有欢乐时光的时候，你去喝一杯，然后离开团队去应酬。关闭整个组织的酒吧往往会给每个人带来不良后果，因此我强烈建议您避免经常这样做。在工作时间之外与您的团队进行大量社交活动已成为过去。

You’re no longer one of the team. Your first team is comprised of your peers at the leadership/executive level, and your reporting structure has now become your second team. If you shift your mindset successfully, you will probably start to detach socially a little bit from the overall organization. When there’s a happy hour, you go for a drink and then leave the team to socialize. Closing down the bar with your whole organization will tend to have bad consequences for everyone, so I strongly advise that you avoid doing that with any regularity. Socializing heavily with your team outside of working hours is a thing of the past.

由于一些原因，您需要分离。首先，如果你不超脱，你很可能会被指责偏心。事实上，如果你与团队中向你汇报的人保持非常牢固的社交关系，你可能会偏爱他人。这很伤人，但这是事实。也许你不在乎，但就我个人而言，我发现让我的团队相信我在玩热门游戏会让整个团队不高兴并且让我的工作变得更加困难。

You need to detach for a few reasons. First, if you don’t detach, you’re likely to be accused of playing favorites. In fact, you probably will play favorites if you maintain very strong social ties with people who report up to you on the team. This hurts, but it is true. Maybe you don’t care, but personally I found that having my team believe I was playing favorites made the overall team unhappy and made my job a lot harder.

其次，你需要超然，因为你需要学习如何有效地领导，而有效的领导需要人们认真对待你的话。在这个级别领导的缺点是，随随便便发表评论，你可能会导致人们改变他们的整个关注点。这很糟糕，除非您意识到这一点并实际适当地使用它。如果你试图保持“伙伴”的形象，你的下属将很难区分他们的伙伴大声思考和他们的老板要求他们专注于某事。

Second, you need to detach because you need to learn how to lead effectively, and leading effectively requires people to take your words seriously. The downside of leading at this level is that with a throwaway comment, you can cause people to change their whole focus. This is bad, unless you’re aware of that and actually make use of it appropriately. If you try to maintain a “buddy” image, your reports are going to have a hard time distinguishing between their buddy thinking out loud and their boss asking them to focus on something.

分离也意味着要考虑你把时间花在哪里。作为高级领导者，您经常会把房间里的氧气吸干。你的存在会改变你参加的会议的基调和结构。如果你不小心，你最终会自以为是并改变项目的方向，因为你在你决定参加的一次性会议上进行了很好的头脑风暴。糟透了！我知道！令人沮丧的是，您不再是其想法需要评估并可能被拒绝的团队中的一员——但您不再是那个人。

Detaching also means being thoughtful about where you spend your time. As the senior leader, you’ll often suck all of the oxygen out of a room. Your mere presence will change the tone and structure of meetings you attend. If you aren’t careful, you’ll end up pontificating and change the direction of a project because you had a great brainstorm in a one-off meeting you decided to drop into. It sucks! I know! It’s frustrating that you can no longer be one of the team whose ideas are there to be evaluated and potentially rejected — but you are no longer that person.

如果您曾与在 Apple 与史蒂夫·乔布斯 (Steve Jobs) 重叠的人共事过，那么您很可能听过那个人谈论“史蒂夫”以及他对他或她正在从事的某个项目的影响。Apple 员工使用史蒂夫的幽灵来支持和反对决策，作为组织应该做什么的道德指南针。您建立和加强的文化会对您的公司产生一定的影响。他们可能不会直呼你的名字，但当你选择在团队面前示范哪些行为时，他们会学习并复制这些行为。如果你大喊大叫，他们就会知道大喊大叫是可以的。如果你公开犯错并道歉，他们就会知道犯错是可以的。如果你总是问关于一个项目的同一套问题，人们就会开始自己问这些问题。如果你公开重视某些角色和责任高于其他角色，雄心勃勃的人会寻找那些有价值的职位。永远使用这种力量。

If you’ve ever worked with anyone who overlapped with Steve Jobs at Apple, chances are you’ve heard that person talk about “Steve” and the impact he had on some project he or she was working on. Apple employees used the specter of Steve to argue for and against decisions, as a moral compass for what the organization should be doing. The culture you build and reinforce will have some of this effect on your company. They may not refer to you by name, but as you choose which behaviors to model in front of the team, they will learn those behaviors and copy them. If you yell, they learn that yelling is OK. If you openly make mistakes and apologize, they learn that it’s OK to make mistakes. If you always ask the same set of questions about a project, people start to ask those questions themselves. If you value certain roles and responsibilities openly above other roles, ambitious people will seek out those valued positions. Use this power for good.

还有其他原因需要分离。您将参与影响整个业务的艰难决策，而这些决策可能会给您带来巨大压力。与公司其他人讨论这些决定是不合适的。向报告团队中那些你认为是朋友的人抱怨你的职位所面临的挑战是非常诱人的，但这是一个坏主意。作为他们的领导者，您很容易因为分担他们无能为力的担忧而削弱他们的信心。在较低级别的管理中可能无害甚至可能有帮助的透明度可能会对该级别的团队稳定性造成极大的损害。

There are other reasons you need to detach. You’re going to be part of hard decisions that will impact the whole business, and these decisions may cause you a great deal of stress. It won’t be appropriate to discuss these decisions with other people at the company. It’s deeply tempting to rant to those people you consider friends in your reporting team about the challenges of your position, but this is a bad idea. As their leader, you can easily undermine their confidence by sharing worries that they can’t do anything to mitigate. Transparency that may have been harmless or even possibly helpful at lower levels of management can become incredibly damaging to the stability of your team at this level.

你可能不是“团队中的一员”，但这并不意味着你应该不再关心团队中的个人。事实上，我鼓励你更多地关心个人，至少在很小的程度上。花时间尽可能多地了解人——询问他们的家庭、爱好或兴趣——是帮助他们感到他们是关心他们的群体的一份子的好方法。

You may not be “one of the team,” but that doesn’t mean you should stop caring about the team as individuals. In fact, I encourage you to care more about people as individuals, at least in a small way. Taking the time to get to know as many people as you can as humans — asking them about their families or hobbies or interests — is a good way to help them feel that they’re part of a group that cares about them.

随着你越来越脱离团队，很容易开始贬低他人并将他们视为齿轮。人们可以分辨出这种情况何时发生，何时他们的领导者不再关心组织中的个人。如果他们觉得没有人真正关心他们个人，他们就不太可能愿意全力以赴、承担风险并克服困难。培养这种联系，即使是表面上的联系，也有助于强化你确实关心他们，而不仅仅是他们当前的项目或工作成果；你知道他们是工作之外的人。它使您扎根，而又不会使您过于依赖个人。作为一名高管，你必须做出艰难的决定，但你的团队值得拥有一位即使在做出这些艰难的决定时也能保持友善的领导者。

As you grow more detached from the team, it can be easy to start to dehumanize people and treat them like cogs. People can tell when that’s happening, when their leaders stop caring about the individuals in the organization. They’re less likely to feel committed to giving their all, to taking risks and pushing through hard circumstances, if they feel that no one really cares about them personally. Nurturing that kind of connection, even at a superficial-seeming level, helps to reinforce that you do care about them and not just their current projects or work output; that you know they’re people outside of work. It grounds you without attaching you too strongly to individuals. You’ll have to make hard calls as an executive, but your team deserves a leader who’s able to be kind even while making those hard calls.

你是一个榜样。你想培养什么样的领导者？你想留下什么样的遗产？

You’re a role model. What kind of leaders do you want to develop? What kind of legacy do you want to leave?

以恐惧统治，以信任引导

Ruling with Fear, Guiding with Trust

卡米尔认为自己是一位优秀的领导者：有技术、有魅力、能够做出决定和完成任务。她有时脾气暴躁，当人们没有达到她的期望或事情出错时，她会明显地生气并公开生气。她并不知道，正是这种锋芒毕露、脾气暴躁的性格，让别人对她产生了畏惧。他们不想冒因失败而受到指责或因犯错而受到公开批评的风险，因此他们会减少风险并隐藏自己的错误。卡米尔不小心创造了一种恐惧文化。

Camille considers herself to be a good leader: technical, charismatic, capable of making decisions and getting things done. She’s also sometimes short-tempered, and when people don’t live up to her expectations or things go wrong, she can be visibly annoyed and openly angry. She doesn’t realize that this hard edge and short temper are making people afraid of her. They don’t want to risk getting blamed for failure or openly criticized for making a mistake, so they take fewer risks and hide their mistakes. Camille has accidentally created a culture of fear.

Michael 还是一位优秀的领导者：技术娴熟、富有魅力、能够做出决策并完成任务。他也善于保持冷静。当事情似乎进展不顺利时，他不会变得紧张和生气，反而会感到好奇。他的第一直觉是提出问题，而这些问题通常会让团队自己意识到哪里出了问题。

Michael is also a good leader: technical, charismatic, capable of making decisions and getting things done. He’s also good at keeping his cool. Instead of getting tense and angry, he gets curious when things don’t seem to be going well. His first instinct is to ask questions, and these questions often cause the team to come to their own realizations about what’s going wrong.

你可能会惊讶地发现你刚刚读到的故事是真实的：当我成为高级领导时，我自己的经历无意中创造了一种恐惧文化。以下是我作为高级领导的第一次评论的摘录：

You might be surprised to learn that the story you just read is true: it’s my own experience accidentally creating a culture of fear when I became a senior leader. Here’s an excerpt from my very first review as a senior leader:

即使是你团队中爱你的人也承认害怕你和你潜在的批评。人们害怕在你面前冒险或失败，因为他们害怕在同龄人面前受到公开谴责。你的攻击所做的是创造一种文化，在这种文化中，团队成员害怕与你互动、向你提问或向你寻求反馈——这会导致你不信任他们和他们犯错的恶性循环。

可以想象，这是一件令人震惊和不舒服的事情。虽然我可以为此找很多借口——人们对来自女性的批评更为严厉，但我来自金融行业，这是一种正常的文化，每个人都需要坚强起来——这显然是个问题。人们害怕冒险，如果你想拥有一个能够设定自己的方向并推动自己的独立团队，你需要他们去冒险。

As you can imagine, this was a shocking and uncomfortable thing to hear. And while I can make dozens of excuses for it — people take criticism more harshly from women, I came from the finance industry where this was a normal culture, everyone just needs to toughen up — it was clearly a problem. People were afraid to take risks, and if you want to have an independent team capable of setting their own direction and pushing themselves, you need them to take risks.

你怎么知道你是否在创造一种恐惧文化？它可能来自对正确和遵守规则的高度重视，以及对基于等级的领导的强烈亲和力。我还相信，来自公开容忍冲突的地方，即使不积极鼓励，也让我更有可能创造这种文化。工程文化对解决冲突的公开辩论具有很高的容忍度，因此来自以工程为重点的背景的领导者可能会特别乐意与他人就问题进行激烈的争吵。不幸的是，当你是领导者时，动态会发生变化，那些在你作为个人贡献者时可能会反击的人会感到你作为领导者的威胁。

How do you know if you’re creating a culture of fear? It can come from placing a high value on being correct and following the rules, and having a strong affinity for hierarchy-based leadership. I also believe that coming from places where conflict was openly tolerated, if not actively encouraged, made me even more likely to create this culture. Engineering culture has a high tolerance for open debate to resolve conflict, so leaders who come from heavily engineering-focused backgrounds may feel particularly comfortable aggressively sparring with others over issues. Unfortunately, when you’re the leader, the dynamic changes, and those who may have fought back when you were an individual contributor will feel threatened by you as a leader.

纠正恐惧文化

Correcting a Culture of Fear

  • 练习相关性。恐惧文化的一个标志是一种以非人格化的方式对待他人的倾向。在我早期的管理生涯中，我有过分关注效率的习惯。我想直接进入手头的问题，进入智力讨论、状态更新和需要解决的问题。我没有花太多时间闲聊，没有花太多时间去了解我的团队，也没有让他们把我看作一个人，因此，我和他们没有太多的私人关系。

    如果你想要一个乐于承担风险和犯错误的团队，核心要求之一就是归属感和安全感。这意味着你需要花点时间闲聊。询问人们关于他们自己的情况，了解他们作为人，让他们了解你。大多数人害怕在他们认为失败后会拒绝他们的人面前冒险。有意或无意地，由于忽略了与我的许多团队成员建立最基本的个人关系，我让他们害怕我对错误、问题和失败的反应。
  • 道歉。当你搞砸了，道歉。练习诚实而简短地道歉。
    “对不起，我不应该对你大吼大叫，我没有任何理由为我的不良行为找借口。”
    “对不起，我没有听你的话，我知道在这种情况下我让你感到沮丧。”
    “对不起，我错了，我忘了告诉你鲍勃的事。”


    道歉不需要拖延。一个简短的道歉，为你在造成负面情况或伤害他人方面的作用负责是必要的。如果你走得太久，它往往会变成借口或分散注意力。道歉的目的是向人们表明你知道你的行为会对他人产生影响，并为他们树立榜样，犯错是可以的，但当你伤害了别人时，你应该道歉。你是在向团队表明，道歉不会让你变得更弱——它会让整个团队变得更强大。
  • 好奇。什么时候你不同意某事，停下来问为什么。并非每一次分歧都会削弱你的权威。当你花时间去寻找更多关于你不同意的事情的信息时，你会经常发现你是在对你并不真正理解的事情做出反应。对于我们这些关心做正确的事或做出最佳决定的人来说，攻击我们不同意的事情会让事情变得更难。当我们攻击时，许多人会逃避或闭嘴，他们知道向我们隐藏信息是个好主意，这样我们就不会攻击或批评他们。当您感到好奇并学习如何将分歧转化为诚实的提问时，您可以更多地了解有关该问题的其他观点，因为您的团队会敞开心扉。这就是您获取最多信息并帮助每个人做出最佳决策的方式。
  • 了解如何让人们承担责任而不让他们变坏。作为领导者，您希望您的团队做好他们的工作。如果他们未能履行职责，您将成为追究他们责任的人。但它不以责任开始，以后果结束。其他元素一路上都需要。你如何衡量成功？团队是否具备成功所需的能力？您是否在此过程中提供反馈？我认为许多领导者忘记了这些要求，并希望他们可以让初级团队通过明确设定目标来实现某些目标，或者相信更有经验的团队永远不需要反馈。想一想你曾让一个人或一个团队因为失败而变得“糟糕”的时候。您是否让自己为帮助他们取得成功负责？当一切都清楚并且你们都尽力而为时，我敢打赌你们会发现问责制伴随着更少的品格判断，因为你们都清楚地看到发生了什么。

恐惧文化在技术领域非常普遍，它在一切顺利的环境中生存得最好。不要被助长不良行为的外部环境所迷惑。如果你害怕但受到尊重，公司在成长，团队正在解决有趣的问题，那么你们可能会相处一段时间。然而，如果你失去了这些要素中的任何一个，你可以期待看到那些有更好选择的人会离开去寻找更好的牧场。我直接知道，当他们对周围发生的其他事情感到沮丧时，拥有一个害怕但尊重你的团队是不够的。因此，努力软化你的粗糙边缘，练习像人一样关心你的团队，并保持好奇心。建立信任文化需要时间，但结果是值得的。

The culture of fear is pretty common in technology, and it survives best in environments where things are otherwise going well. Don’t be fooled by external circumstances that enable your bad behavior. If you’re feared but respected, the company is growing, and the team is working on interesting problems, you might get along OK for a time. However, if you lose any of these elements, you can expect to see people who have better options leave for greener pastures. I know firsthand that having a team that fears but respects you isn’t enough when they’re frustrated by other things happening around them. So work on softening your rough edges, practice caring about your team as humans, and get curious. Building a culture of trust takes time, but the results are well worth it.

真北

True North

高层领导的核心作用有时会被忽视。这个角色由职能领域的高级领导扮演（CTO 负责技术，CFO 负责财务等），为该职能部门的卓越表现设定了基准。我称之为“真北”。

A core role of senior leadership is sometimes overlooked. This role, played by the senior leader of a functional area (the CTO plays it for technology, the CFO plays it for finance, etc.), sets the baseline of what excellence looks like in this function. I call it “True North.”

正北代表了担任职能角色的人在工作时必须牢记的核心原则。对于产品领导者，True North 包括首先考虑用户和他们的需求，尽可能多地进行测量和试验，并拒绝那些不符合团队既定目标的项目。对于 CFO 而言，True North 包括查看数字、工作成本和潜在价值，并确保您已考虑如何使这些数字对公司有利，公司不会意外支出比预期多的钱，团队知道什么时候有超出预算的风险。

True North represents the core principles that a person in a functional role must keep in mind as he does his job. For a product leader, True North includes thinking of the users and their needs first and foremost, measuring and experimenting as much as possible, and pushing back on projects that don’t address the stated goals of a team. For a CFO, True North includes looking at the numbers, at the costs of work and at the potential value, and making sure that you’ve considered how to make those numbers work in your company’s favor, that the company isn’t accidentally spending more money than expected, that the team knows when it’s at risk for going over budget.

对于技术领导者，True North 意味着确保您已完成工作，准备好投入生产。这意味着您已经遵守商定的审查、运营监督和测试政策。这意味着您不会将您认为尚未准备好供用户体验的内容投入生产。这意味着您正在创建引以为豪的软件和系统。

For a technical leader, True North means making sure that you’ve done your job getting things ready to go into production. It means you have honored your agreed-upon policies for review, operational oversight, and testing. It means that you won’t put something into production that you don’t believe is ready for your users to experience. It means you’re creating software and systems you’re proud of.

技术领导者必须帮助在其组织中为不同类型的项目和风险设置真北标准。另一种思考方式是通过风险分析的视角。风险分析并不意味着我们不冒险。一些通常被认为是“坏”的事情在某些情况下可能是好的。这些包括：

Technology leaders must help set the standard for True North in their organizations for different types of projects and exposures. Another way to think of this is through the lens of risk analysis. Risk analysis doesn’t mean that we don’t take risks. Some things that are generally considered “bad” can be OK under certain circumstances. These include:

  • 单点故障
  • 已知错误和问题
  • 无法承受高负载
  • 丢失数据
  • 发布未经测试的代码
  • 性能缓慢

在某些情况和公司中，所有这些风险都是可以接受的。话虽这么说，True North 帮助我们了解在将代码投入生产时必须仔细考虑所有这些问题。仅仅因为这些规则有例外并不意味着我们忘记了它们的存在。

There are situations and companies in which all of those risks are acceptable to take. That being said, True North helps us understand that all these issues must be carefully considered when we put code into production. Just because these rules have exceptions doesn’t mean we forget that they exist.

我将这个概念称为真北，因为重要的是将其理解为一种潜在的推动力，作为我们作为领导者随着时间的推移而发展起来的一种指导本能，并努力帮助我们的团队作为一个整体发展。当我们的团队培养出这种本能时，他们就可以信任自己独立地遵循这些指导方针，而无需太多指导或推动。

I call this concept True North because it’s important to understand it as an underlying pull, as a guiding instinct that we as leaders have developed over time and strive to help our teams as a whole develop as well. When our teams develop this instinct, they can be trusted to independently follow these guidelines without much direction or nudging.

每个职能领域的正北略有不同，因此组织中自然会有紧张感。产品经理可能更关心用户体验，而不是生产支持负担。财务团队可能更关心基础设施的总体成本，而不是可用性风险。这种紧张是健康的，因为它迫使我们考虑所有风险，而不仅仅是我们特定职能部门关心的风险。

The True North for each functional area is slightly different, so there will be natural tension in the organization. Product managers may care more about the user experience and less about the production support burden. The finance team may care more about the overall cost of infrastructure and less about the risks for availability. This tension is healthy because it forces us to reckon with all of the risks, not just the risks that our particular function cares about.

当您审视自己作为领导者的角色时，审视您设定“正北”的方式可以帮助您了解自己的优势和负责的领域。如果您认为自己是技术领导者，那么您的部分工作应该是为关键技术的大部分方面设置真北。作为一家商业公司的首席技术官，我让 True North 负责围绕生产准备、扩展、系统设计、架构、测试和语言选择做出最基本的技术决策。这并不意味着我做出了所有这些决定，但我指导了评估这些决定的标准。我委托 True North 负责移动和特定于 UI 的开发事宜，但敦促这些领域的高级技术人员阐明标准的样子。

When you examine your role as a leader, looking at the ways that you set True North can help you understand your strengths and areas of ownership. If you consider yourself a technical leader, part of your job should be setting True North for large facets of the critical technology. As a CTO for a commerce company, I set True North for most fundamental technical decision making around production readiness, scaling, systems design, architecture, testing, and language choice. That doesn’t mean I made all of those decisions, but I guided the standards by which such decisions would be evaluated. I delegated True North for matters of mobile and UI-specific development, but pushed the senior technical staff in those areas to articulate what the standards looked like.

当他们没有时间深入研究所有细节时，真正的北方领导者依靠他们长期积累的智慧做出快速决策。如果你想成为这种类型的领导者，你必须在职业生涯的早期花足够的时间来磨练这些直觉，以便能够轻松做出快速判断。这意味着保持技术性；跟进项目、语言或框架足够长的时间，以学习比他们的基础知识更多的东西；并且即使您的日常工作不涉及编写代码，也要推动自己不断学习新事物。

True North leaders rely on the wisdom they’ve developed over time to make fast decisions when they don’t have time to delve into all the details. If you want to become this type of leader, you must spend enough time early in your career to hone these instincts in order to be comfortable making fast judgment calls. That means staying technical; following through with projects, languages, or frameworks long enough to learn more than their basics; and also pushing yourself to keep learning new things even when your day-to-day doesn’t involve writing code.

推荐读物

Recommended Reading

  • 阿宾格研究所、领导力和自欺欺人：开箱即用（旧金山：Berrett-Koehler，2000 年）。
  • Brené Brown，大胆：勇敢面对脆弱如何改变我们的生活方式、爱情、父母和领导方式（纽约：Gotham Books，2012 年）。
  • Peter F. Drucker，The Effective Executive（纽约：HarperBusiness Essentials，2002 年）。
  • Marshall Goldsmith 和 Mark Reiter，What Got You Here Won't Get You There: How Successful People Becomes Even More Successful（纽约：Hyperion，2007 年）。
  • Andrew S. Grove，高产出管理（纽约：Vintage Books，1983 年）。
  • L. David Marquet，调头！将追随者转变为领导者的真实故事（纽约：Portfolio，2012 年）。

评估你自己的经历

Assessing Your Own Experience

  • 在在这个级别，您的辅导和指导很可能来自公司以外的人。你不再有经理，你有老板。您是否有专业教练，由工作提供或自己付费？这是一项很好的投资，即使您的工作并不能支付这笔费用。教练可以给你指导和直接反馈，而且不像你的朋友，她花钱听你说话。
  • 除了教练之外，您在公司外部的同行支持网络如何？您认识您所在地区公司的其他高级管理人员吗？同行小组可以帮助您了解其他公司的工作情况，并且是您可以分享经验和获得建议的地方。
  • 有没有特别佩服的技术高层？你欣赏他们的什么地方？如果有的话，你可以做些什么来更像他们？
  • 回想一下您上次需要为部分或全部团队更改优先级的情况。进展如何？什么进展顺利，什么进展不顺利？您是如何将变更传达给您的团队的，他们的反应是什么？如果重来一次，你会做哪一件事？
  • 您对您的业务在可预见的未来的发展方向了解多少？您了解可以帮助您实现目标的技术战略吗？团队需要发展哪些关键领域，例如功能速度、性能、技术创新和招聘，以实现公司的目标？技术演进推动业务发展的瓶颈或机会在哪里？
  • 您与公司高级领导团队其他成员的关系如何？哪些关系好，哪些关系不好？你能做些什么来改善糟糕的关系？您对这些团队成员的优先事项了解程度如何，您认为他们对您的优先事项的了解程度如何？
  • 如果我问你的团队，你和哪些高管相处融洽，讨厌哪些高管，他们能毫不犹豫地告诉我吗？当 CEO 或领导团队做出您不同意的决定时，您是否有能力抛开分歧并支持公司其他人的决定？
  • 您的行为是否像团队的榜样？得知人们每天都在模仿您的行为，您会高兴吗？当您旁听与您的团队开会时，您是主导谈话还是更感兴趣于倾听和观察？
  • 你最后一次问一个你不经常谈论他工作以外的生活的人是什么时候？上次有人发邮件说她病了不能进来，你有没有花一分钟时间祝她早日康复？
  • 您希望您的高级工程师在评估工作和做出决策时考虑的基本原则是什么？或者，如果您更关注组织而不是技术，那么您希望您的经理在领导团队时遵循哪些基本管理原则？

1个Andrew S. Grove，高产出管理（纽约：Vintage Books，1983 年）。

1 Andrew S. Grove, High Output Management (New York: Vintage Books, 1983).

2个Patrick Lencioni，团队的五个功能障碍：领导寓言（旧金山：Jossey-Bass，2002 年）。

2 Patrick Lencioni, The Five Dysfunctions of a Team: A Leadership Fable (San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 2002).

第 9 章自力更生文化

Chapter 9. Bootstrapping Culture

当您担任高级工程主管时，您的部分工作就是设定您职能部门的文化。新任 CTO 的一个常见错误是低估了对工程团队文化保持清晰和深思熟虑的重要性。无论您是在发展新团队还是改革现有团队，忽视团队文化肯定会让您的工作变得更加困难。随着团队的成长和发展，关注您的文化非常重要，就像您关注您所依赖的任何其他重要基础设施一样。

When you are in the role of senior engineering leader, part of your job is to set the culture of your function. A common failing of first-time CTOs is to underestimate the importance of being clear and thoughtful about the culture of the engineering team. Whether you are growing a new team or reforming an existing team, neglecting the team culture is a sure-fire way to make your job harder. As the team grows and evolves, it’s important to attend to your culture as you would attend to any other important piece of infrastructure that you rely on.

在 Rent the Runway，我有机会建立工程团队的许多文化元素。因为在我加入时，团队仍在以经典的、非结构化的“零星创业”模式运行，所以我能够向团队及其成员介绍许多文化结构和实践。这个过程对我来说是一次很好的学习经历。

At Rent the Runway, I had the opportunity to set up many of the cultural elements of the engineering team. Because the team was still running on the classic, unstructured “scrappy startup” model when I joined, I was able to introduce many cultural structures and practices to both the team and its members. This process was a great learning experience for me.

对于许多被创业文化所吸引的人来说，“结构”和“过程”的想法往好里说是毫无意义的，往坏里说是有害的。我看过对创业团队的调查，其中引入结构的想法引起了诸如“缓慢”和“创新粉碎”之类的反应。这些受访者认为，结构是大公司行动缓慢、官僚作风滋生的原因，而且通常是聪明人工作的乏味场所。

For many people who are attracted to startup culture, the ideas of “structure” and “process” are seen as pointless at best and harmful at worst. I have seen surveys of startup teams in which the idea of introducing structure evoked such reactions as “slow” and “innovation-crushing.” These respondents believed structure is the reason large companies move slowly, foster bureaucracy, and are generally boring places for bright people to work.

在与怀疑论者谈论结构时，我试图重新组织讨论。我不谈论结构，而是谈论学习。我不谈论过程，而是谈论透明度。我们不建立系统，因为结构和流程具有内在价值。我们这样做是因为我们想从我们的成功和错误中吸取教训，并以透明的方式分享这些成功并编码我们从失败中吸取的教训。这种学习和分享是组织如何随着时间的推移变得更加稳定和更具可扩展性的方式。

When talking about structure with skeptics, I try to reframe the discussion. Instead of talking about structure, I talk about learning. Instead of talking about process, I talk about transparency. We don’t set up systems because structure and process have inherent value. We do it because we want to learn from our successes and our mistakes, and to share those successes and encode the lessons we learn from failures in a transparent way. This learning and sharing is how organizations become more stable and more scalable over time.

除了为您提供建立流程和结构的方法外，我还希望能帮助您发展公司文化的个人理念。如果你想创建健康的团队，你需要了解什么对你、对你的公司以及对你不断壮大的同事群体来说是重要的。不仅要考虑你关心什么，还要考虑如何随着公司和团队的成长和发展有效地扩展知识和努力。你将尝试结构和过程并从中学习，但如果你没有要测试的基本理论并且你不着手证明或反驳关于该理论的假设，则很难学习。因此，让我们科学地处理这个文化创造练习，看看您如何以合乎逻辑的方式思考您可能需要的文化片段。

I’m hoping to help you develop a personal philosophy on company culture in addition to giving you ways to set up process and structure. If you want to create healthy teams, you need to have a sense of what is important to you, to your company, and to your growing group of colleagues. Consider not only what you care about, but also how you can scale that knowledge and effort effectively as the company and team grows and evolves. You’re going to be trying out structures and processes and learning from them, but it’s hard to learn if you don’t have a basic theory to test, and you don’t set out to prove or disprove hypotheses about that theory. So let’s approach this culture-creating exercise scientifically, and see how you can think about the pieces of culture you might need in a logical fashion.

早期的创业公司吸引了能够处理极高不确定性和风险的人，以换取同样高度的经营自由度。无论这个想法在纸面上看起来多么强大，都无法长期保证公司会成功甚至继续存在很长时间。通常市场是未经证实的。有些标志看起来不错，有些标志看起来很糟糕。可能会有来自其他大大小小的公司的激烈竞争。此外，很少有既定的工作可以建立。代码是不写的。业务规则未设置。在初创企业的背景下需要做出多少决定，怎么强调都不为过，即使是已经发展了几年的企业。从决定技术框架到决定办公室装修，一切都在争夺中。

Early startups attract people who are capable of dealing with extremely high amounts of uncertainty and risk in exchange for equally high degrees of freedom to operate. There is no long-term guarantee that the company will succeed or even continue to exist for very long, no matter how strong the idea seems on paper. Often the market is unproven. Some signs look good and other signs look bad. There may be fierce competition from other companies, big and small. Furthermore, there is very little established work to build on. The code is unwritten. The business rules are not set up. It is hard to overstate how many decisions need to be made in the context of a startup, even one that has been growing for a couple of years. Everything from deciding on technology frameworks to deciding on office decorations is up for grabs.

许多这些最初的决定在他们解决之前会被撤销几次。很容易考虑改变一个不能很好地适应公司技术需求的框架，但是像休假政策、核心办公时间，甚至公司价值观这样的事情都可能在初创公司的头几年发生变化和发展。

Many of these initial decisions will be undone a couple of times before they settle. It’s easy to think about changing a framework that didn’t scale well with the company’s technology needs, but things like vacation policy, core office hours, and even company values could change and evolve in a startup’s first few years.

在早期，领导者愿意做的最重要的事情——领导者通常包括公司中的每个人，而不仅仅是创始人或高管——是选择一个战略并付诸实施。培养面对大量选择的果断性。你有个问题？找出解决方案并修复它。该解决方案不起作用？试试别的。您不需要找到完美的解决方案；你需要找到能让你到达下一个里程碑的东西，无论这个里程碑是下一个版本、下一个增长突飞猛进、下一轮融资还是下一个雇员。

The most important thing for leaders to be willing to do in those early days — and leaders generally includes everyone in the company, not just the founders or executives — is to pick a strategy and run with it. Cultivate decisiveness in the face of a massive number of options. You have a problem? Figure out a solution and fix it. That solution doesn’t work? Try something else. You don’t need to find the perfect solution; you need to find something that will get you through to the next milestone, whether that milestone is the next release, the next growth spurt, the next funding round, or the next hire.

有时，公司决定自己限制决策，就像在放弃头衔的组织中一样。没有头衔在某种意义上是一种决定，但在另一种意义上，它是一种决定，意味着你永远不需要决定某人的头衔，你不需要担心提拔人们获得新头衔，而且你不需要建立将在未来做出关于标题的决定的设备，因为你已经将其作为一个选项删除了。决定现在不做决定是新公司的一个流行选择，因为在少数人的规模上这真的无关紧要。

Sometimes companies decide to limit the decisions themselves, as in an organization that foregoes titles. Having no titles is in one sense a decision, but in another sense it’s a decision that means you never need to decide what someone’s title will be, you won’t need to worry about promoting people to new titles, and you don’t need to build up the apparatus that will make future decisions about titles because you have removed that as an option. Deciding not to decide right now is a popular option for new companies, because it really doesn’t matter at the scale of a few people.

关于组织政治最伟大的著作之一是乔·弗里曼 (Jo Freeman )的一篇名为“无结构暴政”的文章。虽然这篇文章是关于早期女权主义/无政府主义集体的，但弗里曼的见解同样适用于创业文化。假装缺乏结构往往会产生隐藏的权力结构，这是由人类交流的本质和试图扩大这种交流的挑战造成的。有趣的是，弗里曼描述了一组非结构化群体实际上可以工作的环境：

One of the greatest writings about organizational politics is a piece called “The Tyranny of Structurelessness” by Jo Freeman. While the article is about early feminist/anarchist collectives, Freeman’s insights apply equally well to startup culture. Pretending to lack structure tends to create hidden power structures resulting from the nature of human communication and the challenges of trying to scale that communication. Interestingly, Freeman describes a set of circumstances in which the unstructured group can, in fact, work:

  1. 它是面向任务的。它的功能很窄，也很具体，就像召开会议或发行报纸一样。任务基本上构成了团队。任务确定需要做什么以及何时需要完成。它提供了一个指南，人们可以据此判断自己的行为并为未来的活动制定计划。
  2. 它相对较小且同质。同质性对于确保参与者具有用于交互的“共同语言”是必要的。来自不同背景的人可能会为意识提升团队提供丰富的内容，每个人都可以从其他人的经验中学习，但任务导向型团队成员之间的差异太大只会导致他们不断地相互误解。这些不同的人对言行的解释各不相同。他们对彼此的行为有不同的期望，根据不同的标准来判断结果。如果每个人都非常了解其他人以了解细微差别，那么他们就可以适应。通常，它们只会导致混乱，并花费无数时间来解决人们从未想过会发生的冲突。
  3. 有高度的沟通。必须将信息传达给每个人，检查意见，分工，并确保参与相关决策。这只有在团队规模较小并且人们在任务的最关键阶段实际上住在一起的情况下才有可能。毋庸置疑，让每个人都参与进来所必需的互动次数会随着参与者的数量呈几何级数增长。这不可避免地将小组参与者限制在大约五人，或者将一些人排除在某些决定之外。成功的小组可以大到 10 或 15 个，但前提是它们实际上由执行任务特定部分的几个较小的子小组组成​​，并且其成员彼此重叠，以便可以了解不同子小组正在做什么很容易就过去了。
  4. 技能专业化程度低。不是每个人都必须能够做所有事情，但每件事都必须由一个以上的人来完成。因此，没有人是不可或缺的。在某种程度上，人成为可以互换的部分。

弗里曼在这里描述了许多早期创业公司的常见场景。即使整个公司的发展超出了小团队的范围，工程团队也常常强迫自己保持非结构化。雇用完全来自当前团队的专业和社交网络的“全栈”工程师会导致技能专业化程度低和同质性高。强迫团队同地办公可以降低沟通障碍。也许最关键的是，拥有一个仅作为产品或创始人的执行部门运作的工程团队会使团队高度以任务为导向。

Here Freeman describes a common scenario for many early-stage startups. Even when the overall company grows beyond the small group, the engineering team often pushes itself to stay unstructured. Hiring “full stack” engineers who are exclusively sourced from the professional and social networks of the current team results in low skill specialization and high homogeneity. Forcing the team to be collocated lowers communication barriers. And perhaps most critically, having an engineering team that operates solely as the execution arm of the product or founder makes the team highly task-oriented.

我大胆猜测，有些人可能会对普通初创技术组织的这种特征感到愤怒。毕竟，这些工程团队往往是公司高薪的宠儿！尽管如此，非结构化组织要么表现出最终使其不像成员可能希望相信的那样自主的特征，要么由隐藏的等级制度和权力动态运作。在许多情况下，这两件事在某种程度上都是正确的。

I will hazard a guess that some folks may bristle at this characterization of the common startup technology organization. After all, these engineering teams are often the well-paid darlings of the company! Be that as it may, the unstructured organization either displays characteristics that ultimately make it less self-directed than the members might wish to believe, or is run by hidden hierarchies and power dynamics. In many cases both things are true to some extent.

无结构团队的例子也适用于技术决策和流程。在早期的初创公司中，您经常会发现很多意大利面条代码，这是有原因的。当为满足即时任务而完成工作时，在一个由可互换团队处理的统一代码库中，结果通常不是一个更大的深思熟虑的结构，而是这里的调整，那里的黑客攻击——任何事情都可以完成并向前推进. 当我们想让代码具有可扩展性时，我们通常最终会重构意大利面条代码，这并不奇怪，因为重构通常涉及识别和显式绘制结构，以使代码库更易于阅读和使用。

The example of the structureless team also applies to technical decisions and processes. There is a reason that you often find a lot of spaghetti code in early startups. When work is done to satisfy an immediate task, in a unified code base worked on by a team of interchangeables, the result is not usually a larger thoughtful structure, but a tweak here, a hack there — anything to get things done and moving forward. It’s no surprise that we usually end up refactoring spaghetti code when we want to make it scalable, because refactoring usually involves identifying and explicitly drawing out structure in order to make the code base easier to read and work in.

简而言之，这就是结构的价值。结构是我们扩展、多样化和承担更复杂的长期任务的方式。我们对我们的软件这样做，我们对我们的团队这样做，我们对我们的流程这样做。就像强大的技术系统设计师能够识别和塑造底层系统结构一样，强大的领导者能够识别和塑造潜在的团队结构和动态，并以支持团队长期目标和装备个人以达到最佳状态。

That, in short, is the value of structure. Structure is how we scale, diversify, and take on more complex long-term tasks. We do it to our software, we do it to our teams, and we do it to our processes. In the same way that strong technical systems designers are capable of identifying and shaping underlying system structures, strong leaders are capable of identifying and shaping underlying team structures and dynamics, and doing so in a way that supports the long-term goals of the team and equips the individuals to achieve their best.

没有什么比一个等级森严的小团队更荒谬的了。我们都会认为一个由五个人组成的团队，其中第五人向第四人报告，谁向第三人报告，谁向第二人报告，谁向第一人报告，这很奇怪而且可能没有必要。同样，如果一家陷入困境的企业中的五人团队将大部分时间都花在开会上，决定在浴室里存放哪种卫生纸，他们的优先事项似乎就会出现偏差。结构可能来得太早，并通过放慢本应专注于其他事情的团队的速度来造成伤害。

Nothing is more ridiculous than a small team with a rigid hierarchy. We would all think that a team of five people where the fifth reported to the fourth, who reported to the third, who reported to the second, who reported to the first was pretty strange and probably unnecessary. Similarly, if a team of five in a struggling business spent most of their time in meetings deciding which toilet paper to stock in the bathroom, their priorities would seem skewed. Structure can come too early, and cause harm by slowing down a group that should be focused on other things.

然而，在小公司中更常见的是看到结构来得太晚。问题慢慢蔓延。一个人习惯于做出所有决定并经常改变主意。当只有他和其他几个人时，这个策略很管用。但是当他在一个 10 人的团队、一个 20 人的团队、一个 50 人的团队中继续这样做时，你开始看到的是高度的混乱和白费力气。改变主意的代价变得越来越昂贵。

However, it’s more common in small companies to see structure come too late. The problems creep up slowly. One person gets used to making all of the decisions and changing his mind frequently. This strategy works fine when it’s just him and a couple of others. But when he keeps doing it with a team of 10, a team of 20, a team of 50, what you start to see is a high degree of confusion and wasted effort. The cost to change his mind becomes more and more expensive.

我听过的关于初创公司领导力的最好类比之一来自一位朋友 On Freud，他曾在几家不同的初创公司从事工程管理工作。On 将最早的创业公司描述为驾驶赛车。你离地面很近，你能感觉到你所做的每一个动作。你有控制权，你可以快速转向，你感觉事情进展得很快。当然，你也有随时崩溃的危险，但只有当你这样做时，你才会让自己失望。随着您的成长，您将升级到商业航班。你离地面更远，更多人的生命取决于你，所以你需要更仔细地考虑你的动作，但你仍然有控制感并且可以相对快速地转动飞机。最后，你毕业到一艘宇宙飞船，在那里你不能快速行动，而且航向是提前很久设定的，

One of the best analogies I’ve heard for startup leadership comes from a friend, On Freud, who’s been in engineering management at several different startups. On describes the earliest startup as like driving a race car. You’re close to the ground, and you feel every move you make. You have control, you can turn quickly, you feel like things are moving fast. Of course, you’re also at risk of crashing at any moment, but you only take yourself down if you do. As you grow, you graduate to a commercial flight. You’re farther from the ground, and more people’s lives depend on you, so you need to consider your movements more carefully, but you still feel in control and can turn the plane relatively quickly. Finally, you graduate to a spaceship, where you can’t make quick moves and the course is set long in advance, but you’re capable of going very far and taking tons of people along for the ride.

评估你的角色

Assessing Your Role

识别您正在驾驶的船只的大小。这将由公司人数、公司年龄、现有业务基础设施（软件、流程等）的规模以及风险承受能力等因素共同决定：

Recognize the size of the vessel you’re steering. This will be determined by a combination of the number of people in the company, the age of the company, the size of the existing business infrastructure (software, processes, and the like), and risk tolerance:

人们
你拥有的人越多，你需要更周到的结构来让每个人都朝着正确的方向前进。希望对其组织进行高度控制的领导者往往需要更多的结构来确保他们的愿望得到实现。现代公司通常将结构重点放在目标设定上，而不是试图从高层做出所有决定，但不要低估成功设定和传达目标所需的结构。
年龄
公司存在的时间越长，习惯就越根深蒂固。另一方面，一家公司存在的时间越长，它继续生存下去的可能性就越大。
现有基础设施的规模
如果您几乎没有既定的业务规则（例如“这就是我们如何确定向客户收取费用的方式”）并且代码或物理基础设施（例如商店、仓库或库存）很少，那么就不需要结构。另一方面，现有的业务规则和基础设施越多，您就越需要清楚地了解如何处理它们。
风险承受能力
您是否处于监管严格的行业？如果犯了某些类型的错误，您会损失很多吗？还是您身处不受监管的行业，风险很小？您的结构和流程应该反映这一点。一般来说，依赖你的人越多，企业规模越大，即使没有监管要求，你愿意承担的风险也就越小。

结构随着公司的成长和老化而增长。事实上，约翰·高尔 (John Gall) 的《系统论》一书中甚至有一条定律可以说明这一点：1

Structure grows as the company grows and ages. In fact, there’s even a law that accounts for this, from John Gall’s book Systemantics:1

一个有效的复杂系统总是被发现是从一个有效的简单系统演变而来的。从头开始设计的复杂系统永远无法运行，也无法通过修补使其运行。你必须从一个工作简单的系统开始。

你的公司开始时是一个非常简单的系统，只有几个人，随着越来越多的人、规则和基础设施的加入，它演变成一个复杂的系统。当您的团队规模较小但运作良好时，我认为过度设计您的团队结构或流程不会带来巨大好处。然而，在某些时候你会开始经历失败，而失败是调查和确定你的结构需要改变的地方的最佳场所。在创建职业阶梯的例子中，一个人因为缺乏职业道路而退出可能不足以推动你创建职业阶梯，但当多人退出或未能加入时，你可能会重新考虑。您需要权衡缺乏结构给团队带来的价值与失去您可能想要雇用的人员的成本。

Your company started as a very simple system that contained a few people, and as more and more people and rules and infrastructure were added, it evolved into a complex system. I don’t think there’s a huge benefit in overdesigning your team structure or process when your team is small and functioning well. However, at some point you’ll start to experience failure, and failure is the best place to investigate and identify where your structure needs to change. In the creating a career ladder example, one person quitting because of a lack of a career path might not be enough to push you to create a career ladder, but you may reconsider when multiple people quit or fail to join. You’ll need to weigh the value the lack of structure brings the team against the cost of losing people you might otherwise want to employ.

我对领导者的建议很简单：当失败发生时，检查导致这些失败的现实的所有方面。您看到的模式是通过创建更多或不同的结构或删除它来改进您的结构的机会。考虑故障发生的频率及其成本，并对需要进行的更改做出最佳判断。使用失败来指导进化可以让您在正确的级别应用结构。如果故障只发生在系统的一个部分——比如一个团队——你可以尝试解决该团队的结构，而不必改变更大的结构。考试成绩如何？嗯，你可以向成功学习东西，却往往是拙劣的老师。具有讽刺意味的是，虽然运气对失败和成功都有影响，但我们常常将失败归因于运气不佳，而将成功归因于我们自己的行为。正如高尔定律所说，一个有效的简单系统可以演变成一个复杂系统，但这并不意味着应用一个成功的复杂系统的经验教训就可以在其他地方复制这种成功。作为人类，我们倾向于将失败归咎于运气不好，直到无法忽视我们自己对失败的贡献为止。因此，我们不太可能根据失败的教训过度构建我们的团队。另一方面，成功用灵丹妙药来诱惑我们，这是一个可以让一切变得美好的怪异技巧。如果你想从成功中学习，

My advice to leaders is simple: when failures occur, examine all aspects of reality that are contributing to those failures. The patterns you see are opportunities to evolve your structure, either by creating more or different structure or removing it. Think about how often the failure happens and its cost, and use your best judgment about the changes that need to be made. Using failure to guide evolution lets you apply structure at the right level. If a failure is occurring in only one part of the system — say, on one team — you can try to address the structure on that team without necessarily changing the larger structure. What about examining success? Well, you can learn things from success, but it is often a poor teacher. Ironically, while luck plays a role in both failure and success, we often attribute failure to bad luck and success to our own actions. As Gall’s law says, a simple system that works can evolve into a complex system, but that doesn’t mean that applying the lessons from a successful complex system will let you replicate that success in other places. As humans, we tend to blame failure on bad luck until it’s impossible to ignore our own contributions to that failure. Therefore, we’re less likely to overstructure our teams based on lessons from failure. Success, on the other hand, tempts us with the silver bullet, that one weird trick that could make everything great. If you want to learn from success, make sure you can identify the actual improvement you’re seeking when applying those lessons more broadly, and that you understand the context required to repeat that success.

公司的年龄和团队的规模影响了这个问题。如果您所在的公司已经存在一段时间并将继续存在一段时间，那么使用结构（添加或删除）来提高效率是非常有帮助的，即使它需要预先实施一些成本。这是诡计的一部分。学习很少是免费的。分析情况和思考好的外卖需要时间。如果您未来时间的价值小于您当前时间的价值，那么您可能不会太担心节省未来时间。仅仅因为你的公司规模大、历史悠久且稳定并不意味着你可以随心所欲地拥有死板、不变的结构。技术变革通常使以前冒险的行动变得比行动缓慢的替代方案更安全。软件发布频率就是一个很好的例子。许久，频繁发布软件既困难又昂贵，主要是因为您要将软件交付给用户。在现代 SaaS 世界中，错误很容易修复，而且发布错误所涉及的风险远低于没有足够快地扩展功能以跟上竞争的风险。正是这种对旧结构的无条件依恋使许多人对采用结构犹豫不决。但是，如果您在需要时不采用结构，那么事情也会出错。正是这种对旧结构的无条件依恋使许多人对采用结构犹豫不决。但是，如果您在需要时不采用结构，那么事情也会出错。正是这种对旧结构的无条件依恋使许多人对采用结构犹豫不决。但是，如果您在需要时不采用结构，那么事情也会出错。

The age of the company and size of the team plays into this issue. If you’re at a company that’s been around for a while and will be around for a while, using structure (adding or removing) to improve efficiency is very helpful, even if it costs something up front to implement. That’s part of the trick. Learning rarely comes for free. Analyzing situations and thinking about good takeaways takes time. If the value of your future time is less than the value of your current time, then you’re probably not going to worry too much about saving future time. Just because your company is big, old, and stable doesn’t mean you can have as much rigid, unchanging structure as you want. Technology changes often enable formerly risky moves to become safer than the slow-moving alternatives. Software release frequency is a good example of this. For a long time, releasing software frequently was difficult and expensive, largely because you were shipping that software to the user. In the modern SaaS world, bugs can be easily fixed, and the risk involved in shipping a bug is much lower than that of not expanding features quickly enough to keep up with competition. It’s this type of unconditional attachment to old structures that makes many people hesitant to adopt structure at all. But if you don’t adopt structure when you need it, things can also go wrong.

当每个新员工因为没有入职流程而使团队放慢数月时，这就是由于缺乏结构而导致的失败。当人们因为没有晋升或职业发展的途径而经常离开公司时，这就是由于缺乏结构而导致的失败。第三次生产中断是因为有人直接登录到数据库并且不小心删除了一个关键表，这是由于缺乏结构而导致的失败。我之前说过我更喜欢谈论学习和透明度而不是使用结构这个词，因为我们在这里真正谈论的是找出失败的原因，尤其是频繁失败的原因，并试图找出我们可以改变什么来解决对于那些失败。这从根本上讲是关于学习的。

When every new hire slows the team down for months because there is no onboarding process, that is a failure due to lack of structure. When people regularly leave the company because they have no path to advancement or career growth, that is a failure due to lack of structure. The third time you have a production outage because someone logged directly into the database and accidentally dropped a critical table, that is a failure due to lack of structure. I said earlier that I prefer to talk about learning and transparency rather than using the word structure, because really what we’re talking about here is identifying the causes of failures, especially frequent failures, and trying to figure out what we can change to solve for those failures. This is fundamentally about learning.

创造你的文化

Creating Your Culture

文化是做事的方式，无需人们思考。
Frederick Laloux，重塑组织：受下一阶段人类意识启发创建组织的指南

文化是建立初创公司时经常讨论的话题。公司的核心价值观是什么？公司文化是什么样的？新员工“文化契合”吗？“文化契合度”是歧视性招聘做法的口哨吗？

Culture is an oft-discussed topic of building startups. What are the core values of the company? What is the company culture like? Are new hires “culture fits”? Is “culture fit” a dogwhistle for discriminatory hiring practices?

我开始坚信的一件事是文化是真实的；它也非常重要，而且很多人根本不了解。这既是您公司发展的一个简单、自然的结果，也是如果您不倾向于它会很快成为一个问题的事情。有意识地引导团队文化是领导者工作的一部分，要做好这件事，您首先需要理解它的含义。

One of the things I have come to believe strongly is that culture is real; it’s also incredibly important, and it’s something that many people don’t understand at all. It’s both an easy, natural consequence of your company’s evolution and something that can quickly become a problem if you don’t tend to it. Consciously guiding the culture of your team is part of a leader’s job, and to do this well, you need to understand what it means in the first place.

那么什么是文化？文化通常是社区的潜规则。例如，美国文化要求我们握手作为问候，而在其他一些文化中，触摸陌生人被认为是非常奇怪的。你对待不同地位或不同关系的人的方式是你文化的一部分。文化并不意味着每个人都持有完全相同的价值观，但它倾向于引导普遍的重叠，并且它创造了一堆互动规则，如果你根深蒂固，你就不必考虑太多文化。

So what is culture? Culture is the generally unspoken shared rules of a community. American culture dictates that we shake hands as a greeting, for example, while in some other cultures, touching strangers is considered very odd. The way you address people of different standings or different relationships to you is part of your culture. Culture doesn’t mean that every single person holds exactly the same values, but it tends to guide a general overlap, and it creates a bunch of rules of interaction that you don’t have to think much about if you are deeply ingrained in that culture.

人们确实使用文化价值观以外的方法做出决定。例如，他们可能遵守正式或非正式合同的标准。他们可能会进行纯数据驱动的分析并确定最佳结果。但在团队需求必须高于个人需求的复杂环境中，文化价值观是使我们能够团队合作并在面临不确定性时做出决策的粘合剂。这就是为什么弄清楚并引导您的文化是建立成功公司的重要组成部分。

People do make decisions using methods other than cultural values. They may adhere to the standards of a formal or informal contract, for example. They may do a pure data-driven analysis and determine the optimal outcome. But in complex environments where the needs of the group must override the needs of the individual, cultural values are the glue that enables us to work as a team and make decisions when faced with uncertainty. This is why figuring out and guiding your culture is such an important part of building a successful company.

如果您正在组建一家新公司，则无法保证预定的健康文化会消失。您可能希望您可以创建一个有计划的人员社区，一个由志趣相投的人组成的社区，他们将团结在一起创造这个伟大的工作场所和产品。但现实远比这更混乱。现实更像是一场生存竞赛，文化是事后的想法或事后的理由。早期员工将形成这种文化，无论好坏——或者可能是两者兼而有之。

If you’re forming a new company, there’s no guarantee that a predetermined healthy culture will fall out. You may hope that you can create a planned community of people, a community of like-minded individuals who will bind together to create this great workplace and product. But reality is much messier than that. Reality is much more of a race for survival, with culture as an afterthought or a post hoc justification. The early employees will form the culture, for good or for bad — or likely for a mixture of both.

并非每个人都能适应每家公司。你越早意识到这一点越好。有时我们害怕拥有核心价值观，因为我们相信它们会造成歧视。我会争辩说，一套经过深思熟虑的创造的价值观实际上是价值观应该减少科技公司经常发生的表面歧视，有利于创建一个真正的员工社区，他们分享核心原则和沟通方式。创造一种允许将更广泛的人带入您的社区的文化对您有利。“麻省理工毕业的工程师”不是一种文化。“重视技术创新、努力工作、智慧、科学过程和数据的人”可能是。第一个只允许极少数人成功通过它。第二个允许更广泛的人群适应，同时确保这些人实际上具有相同的价值观。

Not every person will fit in at every company. The sooner you realize this, the better. Sometimes we are afraid to have core values because we believe they will create discrimination. I would argue that a thoughtfully created set of values that are actually values should reduce the kinds of surface discrimination that often happen at tech companies in favor of creating a real community of employees who share core principles and ways of communication. It is to your advantage to create a culture that allows for bringing a broader range of people into your community. “Engineers who graduated from MIT” is not a culture. “People who value technology innovation, hard work, intellect, scientific process, and data” might be. The first allows only an incredibly narrow subset of humanity to pass through it successfully. The second allows a much broader set of people to fit, while ensuring those people actually have the same values.

如果你进入一家有核心价值观的公司，这些价值观很可能是由创始人创造的，或者创始人和早期员工创造的，因此它们反映了公司的文化。理解这一点很重要，因为无论您是否意识到，都会根据这些价值观来衡量您。创始团队的价值观将在公司内部得到强化、认可和奖励。我的经验表明，真正拥护并展现公司所有核心价值观的员工往往会自然而然地做得很好。适合他们很容易。他们可能会感到压力很大或工作太辛苦，但他们很受欢迎并且通常很开心。那些不能轻易符合所有这些价值观的人将会有更艰难的日子。这并不意味着他们会失败，但对他们来说会有更多的摩擦，并且可能感觉需要做更多的工作才能适应并被接受。

If you come into a company with core values, those values were probably created by the founders, or founders and early employees, and thus they reflect the company’s culture. This is important to understand, because you’ll be measured against these values whether you realize it or not. The founding team’s values will be reinforced, recognized, and rewarded inside of the company. My experience has shown that employees who truly embrace and exhibit all of the core values of a company tend to do well naturally. The fit is easy for them. They may get stressed out or work too hard, but they are well liked and usually happy. Those who do not match all of these values as easily will have a harder time. That doesn’t mean they will fail, but there will be more friction for them, and it may feel like more work to fit in and feel accepted.

这如何适用于你？如果您是技术主管、联合创始人或 CTO，则此信息具有深远的应用。如果你加入或创建一家价值观与你自己的价值观截然不同的公司，你会感到很大的摩擦，这会让你的生活更加艰难。在最高层次上，所有这些文化一致性都会在你所做的一切中发挥作用，因为你将大量时间花在谈判、协作和跨职能团队合作上。这并不意味着你不能在一家持有与你自己的价值观不同的公司中取得成功。事实上，你完全同意公司高层团队中每个人的每一个价值观是非常罕见的。您甚至可能不同意您家人或朋友中每个人的每一种价值观！仍然，

How does this apply to you? If you are a technical executive, cofounder, or CTO, this information has deep applications. If you join or create a company with very different values than your own, you’ll feel a great deal of friction that will make your life harder. At the highest levels, all of this cultural alignment comes to play in everything you do, because you spend so much of your time in the land of negotiation, collaboration, and cross-functional teamwork. This doesn’t mean that you can’t be successful in a company that holds some different values from your own. In fact, it’s pretty rare that you agree perfectly with every value of every person on the senior team of a company. You probably don’t even agree with every value of every person in your family, or among your friends! Still, the amount of overlap between the traits you value most and the traits your company values most largely determines how easy the fit will be for you.

应用核心价值观

Applying Core Values

无论您是担任创始人还是执行职务，理解和培养文化都是您作为领导者工作的关键部分。以下是有关如何处理此问题的一些建议。

Whether or not you’re in a founding or executive position, understanding and cultivating culture is a key part of your job as a leader. Here are some suggestions for how to approach this issue.

首先，定义你的文化。如果您有一套公司价值观，请将这些价值观映射到您的团队。您可以添加一些对您的团队来说特别的价值观，或者以对您的团队有意义的方式解释这些价值观。例如，在我的 Rent the Runway 技术团队中，我们明确重视多样性。这意味着我们更感兴趣的是你能做什么和你的潜力是什么，而不是让你在筛选过程中符合一组特定的复选框。我们将学习文化置于公司价值观之上，因为我们相信这对我们工程师来说很重要。这种分层的要点是每个子团队都有自己略有不同的文化。一些团队专注于非常专业，在办公室工作的时间非常规律，并且以非常有条理的方式工作。有些团队更喜欢晚点或早点，

First, define your culture. If you have a set of company values, map those values onto your team. You may add a couple of values that are special to your team, or interpret the values in a way that makes sense for your team. On my tech team at Rent the Runway, for example, we explicitly valued diversity. That meant that we were more interested in what you could do and what your potential was than having you fit a certain set of checkboxes in the screening process. We layered a learning culture on top of our company values, because we believed that this was important for us as engineers. The point of this layering is that every subteam will have its own slightly distinct culture. Some teams are focused on being very professional, are in the office for very regular hours, and work in a very regimented way. Some teams prefer later or earlier hours, or less formal meeting cultures, with more room for chatting and hanging out socially.

其次，通过奖励以积极方式展现其价值观的人们来强化您的文化。人们可以在公司全体会议上分享核心价值故事。在我们的技术部门全体会议上，我们会让人们互相喊叫“保持冷静”并超越自我。有些人觉得这个练习不舒服，包括我自己。深入你内心中羞于表扬别人或不好意思分享你的感受的那部分，进入你关心与你共事的人的那部分。您可以以非强迫或虚假的方式分享这些故事。我们作为一个社区讲述的故事将我们联系在一起。

Second, reinforce your culture by rewarding people for exhibiting its values in positive ways. People can share core value stories at company all-hands meetings. At our technology department all-hands meetings, we would have people give shoutouts to each other for “keeping it dope” and going above and beyond. Some people find this exercise uncomfortable, myself included. Reach through the part of you that is shy about praising people or embarrassed to share your feelings, and go into the part of you that cares about the people you work with. You can share these stories in a way that is not forced or fake. The stories that we tell as a community bond us together.

绩效评估最重要的用途之一是评估团队成员的价值观与公司价值观之间的一致性，以及哪些价值观应该成为绩效评估过程的一部分。指出人们何时以及如何展现团队的一些核心价值观。这种做法以积极的方式强化了期望的行为。它还让您了解团队中谁表现出大部分或全部价值观，而谁没有。

One of the most important uses of performance reviews is to evaluate the alignment between team members’ values and the company’s values, and therefore what values should be part of your performance review process. Call out when and how people exhibit some of the core values of the team. This practice reinforces desired behavior in a positive way. It also gives you a sense of who on your team exhibits most or all of the values, and who does not.

学会发现与公司或团队有价值观冲突的人。如果你的公司有“卷起袖子参与进来”的价值观，那么不断把工作推给别人的队友并没有真正遵循公司的价值观。如果你有“快乐和积极是一种选择”的价值观，那么对每一个想法嗤之以鼻并批评一切的队友就会很难适应。有时，人们会改变以接受这些价值观。“快乐和积极是一种选择”其实是Rent the Runway的核心价值观之一，我不会说我来自快乐的工作背景。事实上，我来自一个相当专业和批判的工作文化。但我学会了欣赏以积极的眼光看待事物的价值。那并不意味着我失去了挑剔的眼光，对我来说，完全采用它从来都不是最容易的价值，但它并不是一个交易破坏者。使用核心价值观来指导人们在他们不一致的领域可以帮助你阐明否则可能感觉只是模棱两可的摩擦。

Learn to spot people who have values conflicts with the company or team. If your company has a value of “roll up your sleeves and get involved,” the teammate who continually pushes off work to others is not truly following this value of the company. If you have a value of “happiness and positivity is a choice,” the teammate who pooh-poohs every idea and criticizes everything is going to have problems fitting in. Sometimes, people will change to adopt the values. “Happiness and positivity is a choice” is actually one of the core values of Rent the Runway, and I would not say that I came from a work background of happiness. In fact, I came from a fairly professional and critical work culture. But I learned to appreciate the value of looking at things in a positive light. That doesn’t mean that I lost my critical eye, and it was never the easiest value for me to adopt completely, but it wasn’t a deal breaker. Using the core values to coach people in areas where they are misaligned can help you articulate what otherwise may feel like just ambiguous friction.

最后，将其用作面试过程的一部分。提醒你的面试官团队的价值观，并要求他们明确注意受访者似乎与这些价值观相匹配或冲突的地方。许多采访试图通过我称之为“友谊”标记的东西来确定文化契合度，例如“你愿意和这个人一起被困在机场吗？” 您当然不想雇用您的团队无法忍受的人，但文化契合度并不是要雇用朋友。我与那些我不想在工作之余聊上几个小时的人建立了良好的工作关系，而与我希望被困在机场的人的工作关系糟糕。此外，通过友谊测试确定的文化契合度几乎肯定在某种程度上具有歧视性。人们与具有重要共同背景经历的人建立友谊，而这些经历往往与学校教育、种族、阶级和性别等因素密切相关。通过雇佣朋友获得的捷径通常不是组建强大团队所需的价值观。

Finally, use this as part of your interview process. Remind your interviewers of the values of the team, and ask them to look out explicitly for places where the interviewee seems to match or collide with these values. A lot of interviews try to determine cultural fit by what I would call “friendship” markers, such as “Would you like being stuck in an airport with this person?” You certainly don’t want to hire people that your team can’t stand to be around, but cultural fit is not about hiring friends. I’ve had great working relationships with people that I would not want to chat with for hours outside of work, and terrible working relationships with people I would love to be stuck with in an airport. Furthermore, culture fit as determined by friendship tests is almost certain to be discriminatory in some way. Humans form friendships with people who have significant shared background experiences, and these experiences tend to closely correlate with things like schooling, race, class, and gender. The shortcuts you get by hiring friends are not usually the values you need to form a strong team.

所以，在讨论合身性时不要含糊其辞。请明确点。这个团队的价值观是什么，您在哪些地方注意到任何匹配或不匹配？一个真正重视独立性的非常聪明的工程师可能不适合每个人都必须在所有项目上广泛协作的团队。那些相信最具分析性的争论总是获胜的人在一家重视同理心和直觉而不是纯粹的分析技能的公司中可能不会很好地工作。我使用这些例子是因为这里的所有值在某些情况下是兼容的，而在其他情况下是不兼容的，这就是使它成为一个强有力的衡量标准的原因。了解您公司的价值观是什么，了解您团队的价值观是什么，并思考您个人的价值观。如果还没有写下这些值，请写下来，并尽量明确。使用这个明确的列表来评估候选人，

So, don’t be vague when discussing fit. Be specific. What are the values of this team, and where have you noticed any match or mismatch? A very smart engineer who really values independence may not be a fit for a team where everyone must collaborate extensively on all projects. Someone who believes that the most analytical argument always wins may not work well in a company that values empathy and intuition over pure analytical skill. I use these examples because all of the values here are compatible in certain situations, and incompatible in others, and that is what makes this a powerful measure. Understand what your company’s values are, understand what your team’s values are, and think about what you personally value. Write the values down if they aren’t already written, and try to be explicit. Use this explicit list to evaluate candidates, praise team members, and inform your performance review process.

制定文化政策

Creating Cultural Policy

创建文化政策文件可能很困难，因为从头开始编写这些文件很困难。幸运的是，您需要从头开始创建的文档越来越少，因为越来越多的人公开分享他们的政策和流程，涉及从职业道路到薪酬等级再到事件管理的方方面面。然而，仅仅有一个起点并复制它并不总是足够的。当我尝试推出我的第一个工程职业阶梯时，我通过艰难的方式学到了这一点。正如我在本章前面所说的，添加结构的时间到了，而那个时间通常是事情失败的时候。当我们的人力资源团队正在为工程团队进行薪资审查时，促使我创建职业阶梯的失败发生了。我意识到我们根本没有薪酬结构。由于缺乏结构，大多数人的报酬是根据他们以前工作的薪水和他们的谈判技巧综合得出的。此外，我们很难弄清楚我们需要雇用谁。我们只雇用“高级”工程师吗？那是什么意思？管理或其他角色呢？

Creating cultural policy documents can be hard, because getting started on these documents from scratch is hard. Fortunately there are fewer and fewer documents that you need to start from scratch to create, as more people are sharing publicly their policies and processes for everything from career paths to pay scales to incident management. However, just having a starting point and copying it is not always enough. I learned this the hard way when I tried to roll out my first engineering career ladder. As I said earlier in this chapter, there comes a time for adding structure, and that time is usually when things are failing. The failure that drove me to create a career ladder came when our HR team was doing a salary review for the engineering team. I realized that we had no salary structure at all. Because of that lack of structure, most people were paid based on a combination of their previous jobs’ salary and their negotiating skills. Additionally, we had a hard time figuring out who we needed to be hiring in. Were we only hiring “senior” engineers? What did that mean? What about management or other roles?

在我们的人力资源团队的推动下，我开始创建一个阶梯，我在整本书中都引用了它。我通过询问经营其他初创公司的朋友是否拥有一家公司来做到这一点。我的一个朋友做了，他和我分享了。它有八个级别，从入门级工程师到执行官，分为四类：技术技能、完成工作、影响力以及沟通和领导力。我拿了这个梯子，添加了更多细节，重命名了关卡，然后展开。这个临时搭建的梯子非常简陋。对于每个级别、每个技能，你会得到一两句话来说明一个人在那个级别工作的分类。即使有我提供的一些额外信息，您也可以针对每个类别查看四点。最差的是最早的级别，这些级别是最基本的，对早期职业工程师提供的指导很少。我把新梯子交给了我的团队，甚至用我朋友用来向他的团队传达的相同方式来传达新阶梯。我告诉他们阶梯的存在是为了确保我们在薪酬等事情上是公平的，他们可以用它来与经理讨论他们的水平并学习如何成长。我告诉人们这没什么大不了的，他们不应该执着于自己的水平。然后我花了一些时间谈论 John Allspaw 的博客文章“论成为一名高级工程师”，试图激励团队推动自己。

After a nudge from our HR team, I set out to create a ladder, which I’ve cited in pieces throughout the book. I did this by asking my friends who ran other startups if they had one. One of my friends did, and he shared it with me. It had eight levels, from entry-level engineer to executive, broken into four categories: technical skills, getting stuff done, impact, and communication and leadership. I took this ladder, added a few more details, renamed the levels, and rolled it out. This makeshift ladder was very basic. For each level, at each skill, you got one or maybe two sentences on what classified a person as working at that level. Even with some additional information from me, there were perhaps four points you could look at for each category. The worst were the earliest levels, which were the most basic and provided very little guidance to early-career engineers. I delivered the new ladder to my team, and even communicated the new ladder in the same style that my friend used to communicate it to his team. I told them the ladder existed to make sure we were being fair with things like compensation, and it was something they could use to discuss their level with their manager and learn how to grow. I told people it wasn’t a big deal, that they shouldn’t obsess over their level. I then spent some time talking about John Allspaw’s blog post “On Being a Senior Engineer” in an attempt to inspire the team to push themselves.

长话短说，我的第一个阶梯失败了。

Long story short, my first ladder was a flop.

为什么对我的朋友来说似乎很好用的梯子对我来说却失败得如此严重？我只能推测，但我们公司之间存在一些相当大的差异。我的公司在背景方面非常多样化。我的团队主要来自小公司和初创公司，其中有少数人像我一样曾在大型金融公司工作过，只有几个人主要在大型科技公司工作过。由于这些不同的工作经历，我们没有真正可以借鉴的共同文化习惯。另一方面，我的朋友管理着一个团队，该团队拥有非常庞大、强大的核心人员，他们都曾在同一家大型科技公司工作，因此有更多共同的理解，不需要如此明确.

Why did a ladder that seemed to work fine for my friend fail so badly for me? I can only speculate, but there were some pretty big differences between our companies. My company was very diverse in terms of background. I had a team that was mostly pulled from small companies and startups, with a handful of people like myself who had worked at big finance companies and only a couple who had mostly worked for big tech companies. We had no real shared cultural habits to pull from because of this diverse set of work experiences. My friend, on the other hand, managed a team that had a very large, strong core of people who had all worked for the same large tech company, so there was a lot more shared understanding that didn’t need to be made so explicit.

我分享这个故事有一个非常重要的原因：尽管遵循相同的模板，但我的朋友能够成功，而我却失败了。本课程对于任何想要创建良好团队文化的人来说都是至关重要的。对一家公司有用的东西——一家正在创造某种类型的产品或在某个行业工作的公司——并不总是能很好地转化为另一家公司，即使这些公司有很多共同点。当我们推出各自的阶梯时，我们都在管理初创公司，我们的团队规模相似，但我们需要非常不同的东西才能使我们的团队取得成功。我的第一个阶梯失败了，因为我的团队需要更多细节。轻量级阶梯的目标是让团队不要沉迷于他们的等级和晋升，但缺乏细节反而让他们中的许多人更加沉迷。工程师们争辩说，他们应该处于更高的水平，因为细节含糊不清。它引起了一系列持续的头痛。

I share this story for a very important reason: where my friend was able to succeed, I failed, despite following the same template. This lesson is crucial for anyone who wants to create good team culture. What works for one company — a company that is creating a certain type of product or working in a certain industry — will not always translate well to another company, even if the companies have a lot of things in common. We were both managing startups when we rolled out our respective ladders, and our teams were similar in size, but we needed very different things for our teams to be successful. My first ladder was a flop because my team needed more details. The goal of the lightweight ladder was to keep the team from obsessing over their levels and promotion, but instead the lack of detail caused many of them to obsess even more. Engineers argued that they deserved to be at higher levels because the details were vague. It caused a constant series of headaches.

写一个职业阶梯

Writing a Career Ladder

以下是为您的组织编写职业阶梯时需要考虑的一些重要问题：

Here are some important issues to consider when writing a career ladder for your organization:

  • 征求您的团队的参与。为了写出更好的阶梯，我不得不改变我的方法。首先，我没有自己动手，而是征求了团队中高级经理和工程师的支持，以提供反馈和细节。我让人们强调他们不明白的事情。我请他们提出重写、添加、编辑和细节的建议。我们作为一个小组进行讨论，我们让小组处理他们最关心的阶梯部分。例如，最资深的个人贡献者致力于对个人贡献者级别的技术和技能期望。
  • 寻找例子。其次，我从其他公司的朋友那里得到了更多梯子的例子，以帮助提供一些细节方面的想法。如果你需要写点什么，现在有很多好的工作可以使用，但当时，我不得不通过让人们打印出他们认为可以分享的任何东西来做我的研究，或者给我高水平的笔记。最好的细节来自大雇主的朋友，尤其是那些拥有强大技术声誉的人。可能很难解释在非常高级的技术水平上预期的工作范围，而这些来自大公司的例子确实帮助我们将细节写下来。
  • 要详细。编写好的阶梯时，您将面临的最大挑战之一是勾勒出细节。你想要一些鼓舞人心和描述性但与你的公司相匹配的东西。期望一家初创公司的 50 人工程团队的主管能够管理整个部门是没有意义的，就像在一家大型跨国公司拥有这种期望一样。想一想在决定是否应聘用某人或晋升到某个级别时，您会寻找哪些细节，并尝试适当地包括这些细节。
  • 使用长篇描述和摘要。我把梯子分成两份文件。第一个是速记电子表格版本，让我可以并排查看各种级别属性，并了解它们如何随着级别的增加而演变。这很有帮助，因为正如我所写的，我可以看到我是如何从一个级别构建到另一个级别的，以及这些角色是如何在他们的范围、技能和责任方面扩展的。第二份文件是长版。写长版对我很有帮助，因为我觉得我可以更完整地讲述每个级别的玩家的故事。长阶梯不是仅仅将级别可视化为一组技能和属性，而是读起来有点像对在每个级别上表现良好的人的绩效评估。您和您的员工可以看到这些技能如何协同工作以形成一个完整的角色。你的梯子应该有多少层？您需要再回答两个问题才能弄清楚这个问题。首先，你如何付钱给人们？第二，你如何识别成就？
  • 考虑阶梯与薪水的关系。您的人力资源部门将希望使用职业阶梯来帮助设定薪资期望。通常，每个级别都有一个工资范围，或者该级别的人可以赚取的最低和最高基本工资之间的范围。如果你没有很多级别，你需要有非常宽的薪水区间来说明同一级别的两个人的表现可能非常不同，并说明工程师往往期望获得加薪这一事实经常，尤其是在他们职业生涯的早期阶段。
  • 提供许多早期的晋升机会。一些人建议在阶梯开始时设置很多级别，以说明处于职业生涯早期的工程师期望频繁加薪和晋升这一事实。您可能希望能够在她职业生涯的前两到三年每年提拔某人。如果是这种情况，请创建包含软件工程师角色的多个级别，并为这些级别提供相对较窄的薪资范围，以期望担任这些角色的人员能够快速晋升或从您的公司离职。
  • 在职业生涯的早期阶段使用较窄的薪资区间。许多级别和狭窄的薪资范围意味着您可以快速提拔人员并证明给他们加薪是合理的，同时使您在某个级别的所有人员的薪酬接近相同。如果您担心公平支付并避免可能导致您在同一级别支付男性高于女性的偏见，这很好。不幸的是，很难在接近的级别之间创建足够的细节以允许一个人轻松地区分某个级别的人。
  • 在级别较低的时间和地点使用较宽的薪资范围。宽薪级和少级别使得每个级别的技能之间的区别更加清晰，并且应该更容易分辨谁在哪个级别操作。在水平间距较大的情况下，您希望薪资范围较大，并且希望这些薪资范围重叠。因此，一个软件工程师乐队的收入可能在 5 万至 10 万美元之间，而一个高级软件工程师乐队的收入可能在 8 万至 15 万美元之间。这意味着强大的软件工程师可能比高级工程师赚得更多。您需要这个回旋余地来留住在当前水平上表现良好但还没有准备好承担下一个水平的额外责任的人才。您还会发现自己使用这个回旋余地来雇用处于围栏上的人到较低级别，并期望他们能迅速晋升。
  • 考虑您的断点水平。公司通常会有他们认为“上升或下降”的某些水平。这些是早期职业角色，缺乏晋升意味着此人尚未达到留在公司所需的成熟度或独立性。该策略往往会作为隐式或显式断点级别转化为您的阶梯。人们可以永远坐在那里，永远不会升职但也不会表现不佳的最低水平是多少？这是您的断点级别。对于许多公司来说，它是高级工程师附近的某个地方。走到这一步的人是一个可靠的团队成员，但他可能会根据自己的选择无限期地保持在这个水平。知道这是哪里是很好的。您甚至可能想将其用作您的阶梯级别变得更难达到的点。期望您的团队聚集在这个级别上，
  • 认出成就。一些公司希望对级别保密，但这往往是不可能的。人们会说话。但是，您可以特意强调某些级别，同时对其他级别保密，甚至可能不让员工自己知道。一些人力资源部门有单独的薪酬等级数字，用于跟踪与职业阶梯完全脱节的员工薪酬。我不提倡这样做。但是，我确实鼓励您至少让您的某些关卡成为 keystone 促销，这是共享和庆祝的。我认为晋升为高级工程师是一件大事，晋升为高级工程师以及首席工程师（如果您有这样的职位）也是如此。在管理轨道上，晋升为董事是值得庆祝的，晋升为副总裁也是如此。
  • 拆分管理和技术轨道。在当今时代，很明显您需要单独的轨道来管理和个人贡献。你不希望人们觉得晋升的唯一途径是管理人员，因为不是每个人都适合这个角色。通常，您会看到高级工程师之上的分裂，组织开始指定管理级别和技术级别。但是，您不一定期望高级技术级别的人数与高级管理级别的人数相同。高级管理人员通常是数量驱动的需求。您需要足够的经理来管理团队中的人员。高级技术人员取决于您的团队和产品所需的技术领导能力的复杂性和范围。有可能拥有一个大型团队，而高级技术人员很少，或者是一个拥有很多高级技术人员和较少管理人员的小团队。在这里有一个完美的平衡是不寻常的。
  • 考虑将人员管理技能作为职业中期要求。鼓励每个人都有某种管理或指导经验，然后才有资格晋升到轨道级别以上。对于大多数公司而言，当人们开始展现领导力时，轨道应该分开，无论这种领导力涉及管理人员还是设计软件。但即使在设计软件时，您也要处理其他人和人类需求。优秀的高级个人贡献者仍然知道如何管理项目和指导团队中更多的初级成员，因此考虑将领导经验（通常通过担任技术主管）作为晋升为高级个人贡献者级别的要求。
  • 多年经验。没有人喜欢给人们设置人为的障碍，而多年的经验感觉就像是最人为的障碍。话虽如此，我鼓励您在这个问题上保持明智。在我的阶梯中，我通过对成熟度增加的预期来区分基石级别，这些级别往往与行业经验年限以及年龄相对应。例如，以参谋工程师为例。考虑大型项目需要很大的个人成熟度，在我看来，这是高级工程师的显着特征。成为一名优秀的程序员不足以成为一名优秀的工程师；您需要展示完成和支持一些长期工作的记录才能证明这一称号的合理性。你不必把多年的经验作为等级的严格要求，
  • 不要害怕随着时间的推移而发展。当您编写这样的阶梯时，您正在创建一个需要随着公司的发展而发展的动态文档。您可能会错过一些细节。由于我自己专注于基础架构开发，因此我的阶梯对于专注于前端的开发人员来说很难解释，因此我们需要对其进行调整，以更好地说明在这个世界中成为高级执行者意味着什么。

良好的梯子是招聘、撰写绩效评估，当然还有晋升过程中使用的关键因素。如果您有机会创建这样的文档，请不要害怕让您的团队参与进来。最好的流程和文件反映了整个团队，而不仅仅是你目前的偏见，在小公司设置这些阶梯的最大好处之一是你可以让很多人参与进来，而没有太多的官僚作风过程。

A good ladder is a critical element to use in hiring, in writing performance reviews, and of course in the promotion process. If you have the chance to create such a document, don’t be afraid to involve your team. The best processes and documents reflect the team as a whole and not just your bias at the moment, and one of the greatest things about setting these ladders up in a small company is that you can involve a lot of people without a ton of bureaucracy in the process.

跨职能团队

Cross-Functional Teams

你和谁一起工作？你向谁报告？你和谁合作？在极小的公司（答案：每个人）和非常大的公司（答案：在您加入之前已经建立了一个非常清晰的结构）中，答案都是显而易见的。作为一家成长型公司的领导者，您需要至少一次（可能多次）帮助您的团队和公司回答这些问题。答案应该是什么？

Who do you work with? Who do you report to? Who do you collaborate with? The answers are obvious in both extremely small companies (answer: everyone) and very large companies (answer: there’s a pretty clear structure that was set up before you joined). As a leader at a growing company, you’ll need to help answer these questions for your team and your company at least once, and probably multiple times. What should the answers be?

我想花点时间谈谈我在 Rent the Runway 工作期间经历的最棒的事情之一：我们产品工程组织的演变。我加入时，工程团队大致分为两组：店面，负责面向客户的网站的所有开发；仓库，支持运行仓库操作的软件。我们迅速将店面发展为前端和后端，因为我们将代码从 PHP 单体重写为基于 Java 和 Ruby 的微服务架构。

I want to take some time to talk about one of the best things I experienced in my work at Rent the Runway: the evolution of our product engineering organization. When I joined, the engineering team was divided into roughly two groups: storefront, which did all development for the customer-facing website, and warehouse, which supported the software that ran the warehouse operations. We quickly evolved storefront to be frontend and backend because we were rewriting the code from a PHP monolith to a Java- and Ruby-based microservices architecture.

在我第一年快结束时，我们进行了一项实验。我们有一个我们想为客户打造的新产品，一个基于客户照片评论的功能。因为找到一件合身的衣服对我们的顾客来说是一个挑战，我们希望购物者能够看到其他顾客上传的穿着这些衣服的照片，以及顾客提供的关于他们的正常尺寸、身高、体重和体重的信息。 “形状”（运动型、梨形、曲线型等）。为实现此功能，我们创建了一个跨职能团队。我们有专门从事前端用户体验开发的工程师，也有从事后端服务的工程师。我们有产品经理、设计师、数据分析师，甚至还有客户服务团队的代表。

Toward the end of my first year, we ran an experiment. We had a new product we wanted to build for the customer, a feature based on our customer photo reviews. Because finding a dress that would fit well was a challenge for our customers, we wanted to enable shoppers to see photos that other customers had uploaded showing themselves in the dresses, along with customer-provided information about their normal size, height, weight, and “shape” (athletic, pear, curvy, etc.). To implement this feature, we created a cross-functional team. We had engineers who specialized in the frontend user experience development, and engineers who worked on the backend services. We had a product manager, designers, a data analyst, and even a representative from the customer service team. This cross-functional team worked as a group to design and deliver this feature to our customers.

这个项目取得了巨大的成功。我们相当快地交付了一个很好的功能，并且贡献者都觉得他们理解项目的目标并且能够因为这个跨职能团队而更好地工作。在这个项目之前，我们一直处于“我们对他们”的模式中，你的特定业务职能是“我们”（技术、产品、分析、营销等），而组织的其余部分是“他们”。 ” 创建这些协作单元让人们有机会将整个团队视为“我们”。就组织健康而言，这是一个明显的胜利，因此我们改进了整个组织，让所有产品工程都由这样的跨职能团队执行。随心所欲地称呼他们——“pods”或“squads”或“pillars”——但跨职能产品开发团队是一种流行的结构是有充分理由的。

This project was a massive success. We delivered a good feature, fairly quickly, and the contributors all felt that they understood the goals of the project and were able to work better because of this cross-functional team. Prior to this project we had been deep in a pattern of “us versus them,” where your particular business function was “us” (tech, product, analytics, marketing, etc.), and the rest of the organization was “them.” Creating these collaboration units gave people a chance to see the whole group as “us.” It was a clear win in terms of organizational health, so we evolved our whole organization to have all product engineering performed by cross-functional teams like this. Call them what you want — “pods” or “squads” or “pillars” — but cross-functional product development groups are a popular structure for a good reason. By putting everyone who is needed to make a project successful together in one group, you help the members of those teams focus on the project at hand, and you make the communication for the whole group much more effective.

在讨论这种结构时经常引用康威定律。它指出：“设计系统的组织……被迫产生设计，这些设计是这些组织的通信结构的副本。”

Conway’s Law is often cited in discussions of this kind of structure. It states: “Organizations which design systems…are constrained to produce designs which are copies of the communication structures of these organizations.”

当我们将跨职能团队放在一起时，我们承认最重要的沟通——我们最需要支持的沟通——是导致有效产品开发和迭代的沟通。请注意，这种结构不一定会产生最有效的技术！事实上，与具有更以工程为中心的团队结构的公司相比，它可能会产生一些效率低下的系统。因此，如果您采用这种结构，则必须决定您愿意在哪些方面进行系统设计，以便最有效地创建产品。

When we put cross-functional teams together, we are acknowledging that the most important communication — the communication that we need to favor above all else — is that which leads to effective product development and iteration. Note that this structure will not necessarily produce the most effective technology! In fact, it will probably produce systems that have some inefficiencies compared to companies that have a more engineering-centered team structure. So, should you adopt this structure, you have to decide where you’re willing to take some system design hits in order to most effectively create products.

构建跨职能团队

Structuring Cross-Functional Teams

这种“吊舱”结构的具体细节是如何工作的？经常引起焦虑的一个因素是谁在管理谁。当我们搬到这个团队组织时，我们并没有改变管理结构。工程师由工程经理管理，并向我汇报。产品经理向产品负责人报告。但是确定谁在做什么主要是由 pod 本身完成的。这意味着您仍然可以从工程经理那里获得技术指导和监督，但您的日常工作取决于吊舱路线图的需求。

How do the nuts and bolts of such “pod” structures work? One element that often causes anxiety is who is managing whom. When we moved to this team organization, we did not change the management structures. Engineers were managed by engineering managers and reported in to me. Product managers reported to the head of product. But determination of who was working on what was done largely by the pod itself. This meant that you could still get technical guidance and oversight from your engineering manager, but your day-to-day work was determined by the needs of the pod’s roadmap.

当然，每个功能都有自己的重点需求。通常工程人员需要监督关键的核心系统，你可能需要一些专家来处理核心网络平台、移动或数据工程等事情。我将这些功能保留在一个通常不分配给产品开发的小型基础设施组织中。即使有一个专门的基础设施组，分配到产品组的工程师仍然需要一些时间来处理特定于工程的任务，如随叫随到、面试和维持工程（也称为技术债务）。我建议保留所有工程时间的 20% 用于此类工作，这完全基于我个人的经验和我同行在工程管理方面的经验。

Of course, every function has its own focused needs. Usually someone in engineering needs to oversee critical core systems, and you probably need a few specialists around for things like the core web platform, mobile, or data engineering. I kept these functions in a small infrastructure organization that was not generally assigned to product development. Even with a dedicated infrastructure group, the engineers assigned to product pods still need some time to account for engineering-specific tasks like on-call, interviewing, and sustaining engineering (aka technical debt). I advise reserving 20% of all engineering time for such work, based purely on my personal experience and the experience of my peers in engineering management.

这种跨职能结构并非小型初创公司所独有。许多大公司也以这种方式构建他们的团队。例如，银行通常有专门负责业务特定领域的技术团队，虽然管理结构由工程师组成，但路线图和日常工作由业务部门及其部门的需求共同决定。相关的工程团队。通常有一个集中的基础设施团队，它支持基础系统以及大型框架和技术，这些框架和技术将被整个公司的许多团队使用。甚至许多科技公司也是这样组织的，尽管“业务部门”本身可能由担任产品或业务经理而不是业务专家的前工程师领导。

This cross-functional structure is not unique to small startups. Many large companies also structure their teams in this fashion. Banks, for example, often have technology teams that are attached to specific areas of the business, and while the management structure is formed by engineers, the roadmap and day-to-day work are jointly determined by the needs of the business unit and its associated engineering team. There is generally a centralized infrastructure team that supports both fundamental systems as well as large frameworks and technologies that will be used by many teams across the company. Even many technology companies are structured in this way, although the “business units” may themselves be headed by former engineers who act as product or business managers instead of business specialists.
